"Am√©ricas Queer: Art and Literature" | This course explores how North and South have understood (and misunderstood) each other on issues relating to gender and sexuality, while it also seeks to give students an introduction to the rich literature and art of Queer Latinx Americans. Particular attention will be paid to how the AIDS crisis of the 1980s brought to light conflicts between sexual identity, and identity politics. While issues of race, class and sexuality impacted Latinx populations in the US, activists and writers in Latin America confronted issues relating to imperialism and sexuality.


Authors include: Mario Bellatin, William Burroughs, Rita Indiana Hernandez, Salvador Novo, Manuel Ramos Otero, Achy Obejas, Nestor Perlongher, Gloria Anzaldua, Cherrie Moraga, Reinaldo Arenas, and others


Requirements:: Three short papers, midterm, oral reports.
Grading: Papers: 15% each 
Midterm: 20%
Written Commentaries , 20%, 
Attendance and participation, 15%
course_description: An introduction to different methods of literary criticism and textual interpretation, applying a variety of theoretical approaches to selected literary texts.  Readings include essays, fiction, poetry, and drama. *Note: This course is non-repeatable.
